messages.message: By the way - just want to confirm this again. How does adding a collaborator works now?
what specifically seems different here Kerry? FYI @Heymian — i haven’t noticed a difference — which specific repo or situation are you referring to here?

@dlluncor a week or two ago @Jessica lost access to `ib_sales/sales-demo`, Aaron V and I both tried to add her as a collaborator, we can see her name in the collaborator list but she cannot see the repo.
Yeah that changed. All site admins no longer had god-like ability to see/edit all orgs across instabase. You have to be explicitly added as an org admin to be able to access the org.

Dylan posted this in `team-customer-success` channel:
```
@dlluncor - I believe you said that we now need the owner of the repo to elevate people to admin for each repo (did I get that correctly?) (edited) 
```
So I wonder if the behavior has changed. If we change who can add collaborators we should take out the `Add Collaborator` button for users who cannot do this.
When you said “she could not see the repo” what does that mean?
did the repo not show up in the repo list? or did she get “access denied” when she tried to click into it?
I got access denied when I clicked on the repo
^ yeah so repos have ACL bits enabled by default. So you need to get added to the ACL JSON for the drive /each app via Manage ACLs.
adding as a collaborator just allows the repo to show up in the list of repos on the org page. but to go into it and do anything you need more bits.

So this is something we should change in the frontend to avoid confusion cc @Jessica
@Heymian is there an API to know if a user is an admin of a repo? or get a list of admin of a repo?
btw do we have a release note for this
yeah it was added (it’s a env var config that can be configured per instabase install)
and yup you can tell what permissions you have on a repo

Got it. Understand what you are referring to now Kerry. Yes we are using an Instabase which is more reflective of our enterprises use it. For org owned repos, you either need to be an org admin to get all permissions. If you are not an org admin, then you must receive specific ACLs to access various parts of the repo.

To make things simpler for us for now, the easiest way is to make each of us org admins for the organization
That way you don't have to mess around with ACLs and give certain people specific access to some folders and not other. Our error messaging here is definitely not the easiest.
